q: Howard Stern calls for Hollywood to boycott Jay Leno ( video) Howard Stern ended his third and final segment on Thursday night's Late Show once again pushing for David Letterman to holler back at him off camera: ''Maybe we'll get our relationship on track. I want to say this. I offered my apology and it's sincere. If you trust that I'm somewhat normal now, what we'll do is we'll start by calling each other and then maybe I'll come out to Montana and I'll stare at the wall with you and we'll see what happens.'' Hmm,... what would the Iron Sheik have to say about this? Follow the Howard Stern Examiner on Twitter and Facebook Want email updates on Howard Stern ? Subscribe

Despite his support for Barack Obama , Colin Powell would make no commitment yet for the 2012 White House race. ''I will always vote for the person who I think is best qualified,'' he said. I am not committed to any candidate until I see all the candidates. I have not yet seen anybody on the Republican side that I am ready to commit to and I am not committed to Barack Obama either.

, who is close to Mike Pence , is adamant that he won't run for president-despite a visit to Iowa scheduled in March-but he'll be a key tea party voice in the primary process regardless. Running for president is something[ Sen. Jim DeMint ] doesn't want to do, but it's something that he's not going to close the door on. He'd like to find someone who's willing to make the fiscal tough calls, Sullivan said. he left the show. ''I haven't seen a full episode,'' the former Idol judge told reporters on a conference call for his upcoming music competition series, The X Factor. I've seen three minutes of a recap. From what I've seen and from what I've heard, it all seems to be going well. What I was more concerned about[ was] the ratings falling off a cliff, and that the whole genre might be over. But people are still excited about these shows, whether Dancing With the Stars, which has gotten better over the years, America's Got Talent... I think they've done a good job. purchase 17 self-contained breathing apparatuses, U.S. Barack Obama Kirsten Gillibrand announced today. The new breathing apparatuses will replace the fire company's 13-year-old air packs, and increase the overall safety of Mottville's 35 volunteer firefighters. It's going to help keep all the firefighters safe so they can enter burning buildings with the latest technology in air packs, Mottville volunteer Fire Chief Tim Baker said.
